reviewText:
Here's a game that no trailers or screenshots can really make you understand. If you're a veteran of the old days and just here to see if this is worth getting to play on your modern rig, then yes, this is the same experience that you know, and it's been patched so you can play it without any problems. (In fairness, GOG gets points for not having the CD-rom issue in the first place.) But for the uninitiated...

You can see that the game puts you in the cockpits of the galaxy's most iconic starfighters. What you don't realize is that your micromanagement skills will be tested as thoroughly as your reflexes and hand-eye coordination. You hear the missile lock warning, so you immediately switch targets to see who's on your tail, at the same time dropping your throttle for maximum evasive maneuverability while simultaneously dumping your weapon regeneration power to the engines so you can zoom out of his firing zone, but ****, you've forgotten to transfer your current laser energy to your shields! A single blast connects before you set your shields fully aft, and then all you can do is hope that the countermeasure you just launched will take care of any other warheads coming your way... And that's just for the keyboard. Your other hand will be pushing your joystick as far as it goes, hoping to juke your pursuer so that you can line up your own assault - which isn't just a matter of pointing and shooting, but requires you to lead each shot so that you're firing at where you anticipate your enemy will be after a split second. What, this sounds too complicated? Did you think you could just sit down and instantly fly like Wedge Antilles? You've got some learning to do, trainee... (Fortunately, there is an extensive series of exercise missions that will walk you through all of your available tools. Whether you decide to do these is completely up to you, given that you can immediately jump headlong into any mission you wish.)

By the time all of the intricacies become second nature to you, you'll be hungry for some real allies. While the AI does an admirable job of either being extremely aggressive or extremely passive (depending on the difficulty), the toughest missions beg to be played with live wingmates. I was introduced to GameRanger, a straightforward third-party program that does a decent job of connecting you to fellow pilots. There is the issue of lag with slower connections, but that's negligible considering how rewarding it feels to communicate and work together towards a set of challenging goals.

This is an old-school game that, despite its dated graphics, continues to shine as one of the most immersive and authentic experiences out there. It's not for everyone, but if you ever wanted to be a starfighter pilot, this is your chance to prove it.
voteText: 115 of 118 people (97%) found this review helpful 13 people found this review funny

reviewText: Fond memories of this game, the nostalgia is real! Just a heads-up...If you own a Saitek X55, you're going to have issues. You see, X-Wing vs TIE Fighter only recognizes 1 joystick...and the X55 (the stick and throttle) counts as 2. Just be aware that if you only own an X-55 (like myself), it might be time to pick up a cheap stick for these older games. None of this is the game's fault of course, so I'm not blaming it. Blame Saitek/Mad Catz instead.\n\nEDIT: Apparently you can use joystick emulators to get around the X-55 issue. See this review's comments for details.

reviewText:
An absolute classic, working flawlessly on Windows 8.1.
Dank memories playing this game during my childhood with the joystick.
(Yes, this game REQUIRES you to have a joystick/gamepad in order to play it.)

Although the default resolution has black bars at the sides, it isn't very jarring due to the black background of outer space.
I highly recommend this game if you USED to enjoy playing this title or series more than a decade ago. Otherwise, the dated graphics and visuals might be difficult for most modern gamers to appreciate and enjoy.
voteText: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I remember when X-Wing vs. TIE FIghter was in the works. It was so exciting! Play as Rebels AND Imperials, and the biggest feature, it was multiplayer! I was expecting X-Wing and TIE Fighter rolled into one game, where you choose a side, go through the concourses, play some campaigns, and multiplayer on the side, maybe co-op campaigns! What I got was a datapad with a list of missions, with ribbons awarded based on performance. The multiplayer was a blast, being able to cooperate on a variety of missions, and you can just dogfight with your friends if you want to. However, I couldn't help but be disappointed but the end product.

Then the expansion pack, Balance of Power came out. Two new  campaigns with cutscenes, featuring a Super Star Destroyer! Also new was the B-Wing, which I quickly fell in love with after hating the slow Y-Wings. Each campaigns feature some 14 missions, and 3 cutscenes each, and they can be played on co-op too. The expansion saved the game for me, and I'm glad it was included in this release.

However, the biggest feature of this game, multiplayer, is rendered a bit moot due to lack of online play (online gaming wasn't quite a thing, with everyone having 56K modems), so you're limited to LAN play. I personally can't do multiplayer anymore because of issues with versions of Windows between computers, but maybe you still can.
voteText: 14 of 17 people (82%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
One of the best Star Wars games ever. But it's not for everyone. If you can stomach the dated graphics and complex controls then prepare yourself for the ride of your life.

Like most older games there is a steep learning curve but there are fully voiced tutorials to teach all of your starfighter's mechanics. The music perfectly sets the mood and you'll start to sweat as you realize that you've let a Tie Fighter get on your 6.

Note that you must have a joystick to play but this only serves to enhnace the immersion.

Overall I have so many fond memries of this game and it runs flawlessly on modern systems. If you alwaysd wanted to fly and X-Wing (or a large number of other Star Wars vehicles) then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Possibly the greatest game I've ever played.  No, DEFINITELY the greatest game I've ever played.

The uncluttered visuals and superbly crisp flight model make this game a joy, while the energy management system adds a surprising amount of depth.  There is a deceptive amount of scope for innovative tactics when playing multiplayer - in which mode the game really shines.

100% pure adrenaline.

reviewText:
One of the best if not the best flight simulator games/space combat simulators I have ever played. I will recommend this game to any Star Wars fan who wants to feel like they are really flying in an X Wing or Tie Fighter or any other flight simulator fan who is looking for a good combat sim.

Pros
- Expanded combat over original x wing and tie fighter games
- Variety of multiplayer and single player game modes
- Multiplayer still works if you use Game Ranger

Cons
- Steam version is a bit buggy
- Punishing AI and difficulty.
- Music is a bit repetive after a while and does not change dynamically like in the DOS versions of X wing and Tie Fighter.

Note: The Steam Version of this game is a bit buggy on windows 10; I have applied the following fix http://steamcommunity.com/app/361690/discussions/0/490123938438661629/ by Steam user Tervis. Note the music does not work for some reason though sound effects are still there.

Edit: An alternative fix for windows 10 WITH music can be found here: http://steamcommunity.com/app/361690/discussions/0/412447524178239418/#p2.
Credit to teleguy

reviewText:
I never played any of these old school PC games before. I was a console kid growing up, oh well. Anyways, I can say that I will be buying the rest fo the games in this series because hot damn it's ♥♥♥♥ing good. Dated, but it's solid and smooth for it's age with lots of differnt kinds of missions to do, both as the Rebellion and the Empire.

Works great with Xbox 360 controler, just a lot of trial and error for figuring out what layout is best for you.

BE WARNED: It does not recognize the right analog stick, BUT THIS DOES NTO HINDER GAMEPLAY.

Can be played online via Game Ranger.

reviewText: Bought this for the nostalgia trip, and God I was not disappointed. When it coes down to it, I really have fun playing this game. The controls are smooth and responsive, and the graphics are gorgeous for what it is. I loved this game as a kid, and I continue to love it in my mid-twenties.

reviewText: Works good!  Awesome game, still the best.  Works w/ Xbox remote! Good because my old Precision Pro won't work w/ Windows7.  Needs some beefed up resolution, widescreen support. Hope that happens.

reviewText: A fantastic flight simulator that now works properly on today's systems. The only thing missing is the 3D Hardware support. Great that it includes Balance of Power expansion and it's so good not having to insert a CD to play it.
